snippet: Researchers say a significant share of the bacteria in India — in its water, sewage, animals, soil and even its mothers — are resistant to nearly all antibiotics.
abstract: Number of infants born in India with antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections continues to rise at alarming rates; more than 58,000 such infant deaths occurred in 2013 alone; many researchers say evidence is overwhelming that significant share of bacteria present in India are immune to nearly all antibiotics, expressing worry that so-called superbugs could have global implications.
lead_paragraph: Researchers say a significant share of the bacteria in India — in its water, sewage, animals, soil and even its mothers — are resistant to nearly all antibiotics.

headline.main: ‘Superbugs’ Kill India’s Babies and Pose an Overseas Threat
headline.print_headline: ‘Superbugs’ Kill India’s Babies and Pose an Overseas Threat
